shortTermOutlook.stateDescription: Recent bearish events outweigh bullish events.

intermediateTermOutlook.stateDescription: Recent bullish events outweigh bearish events.

msBullishSummary: A new focus on dermatology, ophthalmology, and gastroenterology will pave ways for many untapped opportunities that Viatris can utilize with its scale and manufacturing power.
Effective portfolio optimization and a promising pipeline of first-to-market launches will provide solid top line tailwinds.
Exiting biosimilars business will reallocate resources and help the company focus on long-term goals in its core generic and branded markets.
msBearishSummary: Base business erosion will continue to persist in developed markets and act as headwinds that Viatris must try to offset with new product launches.

The majority of Viatris’ business in China is off-patent branded drugs, and volume-based procurement as well as an improvement in the country’s generic dispensing rate will narrow the company’s addressable market in the region.

Failure to successfully develop pipeline and launch products could see the company lagging its competitors in terms of innovation and development, especially since Viatris has exited biosimilar opportunities.

researchReports.title: Viatris Earnings: Firm Wraps Up 2023 on a Solid Note; New Partnership Bolsters Pipeline
researchReports.summary: Viatris was formed in November 2020 through the combination of Upjohn, a wholly owned subsidiary of Pfizer that specialized in off-patent drugs, and Mylan, a global pharmaceutical manufacturer that focused on generic and specialty drugs. By joining forces, Viatris became one of the largest generic drug manufacturers in the world, servicing over 165 countries. Generics (commoditized and complex) and biosimilars make up roughly 40% of Viatris' total sales. Remaining 60% of sales is derived from its portfolio of legacy products which includes Lipitor, Norvasc, Lyrica, and Viagra. While it covers more than 10 major therapeutic areas, Viatris has identified dermatology, ophthalmology, and gastroenterology as its three key areas of focus for future innovations.

reports.reportTitle: Stocks fluctuated in volatile trading on Thursday morning, but were nearly flat at midday. Disney shares rose 7% after the company reported better-than-expected fiscal 4Q EPS and announced plans to cut an additional $2 billion in expenses. Disney and other content providers, including Netflix and Paramount, also benefited from a tentative agreement ending the Hollywood actors strike. On the employment front, first-time claims for state unemployment benefits fell by 3,000 to a seasonally adjusted 217,000 for the week ended November 4, slightly below the Reuters consensus forecast. The Dow was flat, the S&P rose 0.1%, and the Nasdaq rose 0.2%. Crude oil rose 1% to $76 per barrel, while gold traded near $1968 per ounce.

reports.reportTitle: The stock market sometimes gives a warning after a large move higher, gets everyone believing that a pullback has finally arrived, and then regroups for a couple of days before the rug is pulled out yet again. On July 27, we saw a pretty ugly reversal in the major indices that looked like the start of a much-anticipated reset. That was not to be, however, with stocks broadly higher on July 28.

Viatris Inc., based in Pennsylvania, is a specialty and generic drug company formed in 2020 through the combination of Pfizer's Upjohn business and Mylan N.V. The shares are a component of the S&P 500. The company has 37,000 employees.

Stocks edged higher on Wednesday morning, led by gains in the Communication Services, Energy, and Materials sectors. Investors weighed weak economic data from China, where exports plunged 7.5% from the prior year in May, along with new GDP growth forecasts from the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. The OECD now projects global economic growth of 2.7% this year, up slightly from its prior forecast of 2.6%, and 2.9% growth in 2024, unchanged from its previous estimate. On the earnings front, United Natural Foods shares dropped 25% after the food distributor posted weaker-than-expected fiscal 3Q earnings and lowered its full-year guidance. The Dow rose 0.1%, the S&P 0.2%, and the Nasdaq 0.4%. Crude oil traded near $72.50 per barrel, while gold rose $4 to $1986 per ounce.

Viatris Inc., based in Pennsylvania, is a specialty and generic drug company formed in 2020 through the combination of Pfizer's Upjohn business and Mylan N.V. The shares are a component of the S&P 500. The company has 37,000 employees.

In the equity markets, the VIX Volatility Index is elevated but has improved of late -- suggesting that investors may have grown a bit more confident over the past two weeks. Recent insider-sentiment data from Vickers Stock Research matches that pattern. For over a month, the proprietary one-week sell/buy ratios from Vickers were screamingly bearish -- and, indeed, stocks fell broadly during that time (with the DJIA off over 6%). Then, two weeks ago, the ratios jumped right over neutral and landed in bullish territory -- and stocks reacted again, with the DJIA up about 2.5% since mid-March.

Viatris Inc., based in Pennsylvania, is a specialty and generic drug company formed in 2020 through the combination of Pfizer's Upjohn business and Mylan N.V. The shares are a component of the S&P 500. The company has 37,000 employees.

Stocks were mostly lower on Wednesday morning amid continued concerns about Fed rate hikes and a potential recession. Campbell Soup shares rose after the company topped fiscal 1Q revenue and earnings estimates, while Carvana shares plunged more than 30% after an analyst downgrade that warned of an increased risk of bankruptcy for the used car retailer. The Dow was flat, the S&P fell 0.2%, and the Nasdaq fell 0.5%. Crude oil fell 2% to $73 per barrel, while gold traded near $1794 per ounce.

Viatris Inc., based in Pennsylvania, is a specialty and generic drug company formed in 2020 through the combination of Pfizer's Upjohn business and Mylan N.V. The shares are a component of the S&P 500. The company has 37,000 employees.

reports.reportTitle: Stocks plunged on Friday morning on further signs of accelerating inflation and concerns about the Fed's response. In a widely anticipated release, the Labor Department said that consumer prices rose at an 8.6% annual rate in May, up from 8.3% growth in April and above the consensus forecast of 8.3%. The reading was the highest in more than 40 years. The core CPI, excluding food and energy, rose 6.0% from the prior year, above the consensus of 5.9% growth. The Dow fell 2.1%, the S&P 2.5%, and the Nasdaq 3.1%. Crude oil fell to $121 per barrel, while gold traded near $1851 per ounce.

Viatris Inc., based in Pennsylvania, is a specialty and generic drug company formed in 2020 through the combination of Pfizer's Upjohn business and Mylan N.V. The shares are a component of the S&P 500. The company has 37,000 employees.

Stocks are mostly higher Friday morning. Meanwhile, cryptos are mixed. Existing Home Sales were lower than expected in February, slowing to an annualized rate of 6.02 million homes sold. The Dow fell 0.2%, the S&P rose 0.3%, and the Nasdaq was up 1%. Crude oil traded at $103 per barrel, while gold fell $7 to $1936 per ounce.

U.S. equites pulled back on Monday morning on debt concern in China, as well as well as apprehension about the timetable of the Fed's tapering of asset purchases ahead of the FOMC meeting. On the housing front, builder sentiment rose 1 point in September to 76. Building products pricing has moderated but labor costs remain high. The S&P 500 fell 1.7%, the Dow was down 1.6% and the Nasdaq declined 2.2%. Crude oil 1% to just above $71, while gold fell $13 to $1765.

reports.headHtml: Market Digest: CMA, ERIC, GSK, KEY, NFLX, VTRS
reports.reportTitle: Sector Rotation Showing Signs of Reverting

The first quarter was good for stocks, as the S&P 500 increased more than 6.0%.  The average stock in the Argus Fundamental Universe of Coverage advanced more than 13%, and the median stock gained 9.6%.  The average BUY-rated stock increased 12%, while the average HOLD-rated stock rose 16%. Will investors continue to favor value and small-cap? Given low interest rates, we expect growth stocks to outperform over time, but think that 2021 may be the "one-in-five years" that value leads. Investors seeking value are encouraged to focus on dividends and look for yields in the 3%-4% range. For small-caps, the vaccine is encouraging as these companies typically don't have the gilt-edged balance sheets of large-caps and are more dependent on a strong U.S. economy. Small-cap valuations remain depressed despite the recent run, and this group continues to look well positioned in 2021.

The Argus Research Fundamental Universe of Coverage includes approximately 500 leading U.S. and international companies.  We cover the waterfront -- from Technology to Utilities to Energy to Healthcare. Generally, we follow the Top 200 most widely held stocks, which we source from our sister company Vickers Stock Research (which collects institutional ownership data from the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission).  From there, we look to identify the next 200-300 leading U.S. and international companies to add to our list.  Our Universe of Coverage is dynamic and growing.  We are continually adding stocks to coverage and often get great ideas from our clients.  Here are five of our most recent additions.

Viatris Inc., based in Pennsylvania, is a specialty and generic drug company formed in 2020 through the combination of Pfizer's Upjohn business and Mylan N.V. The shares are a component of the S&P 500. The company has 35,000 employees.

Since we last commented on insider sentiment two weeks ago, insider-transaction volume has been (as expected) muted due to the holiday season. On light volume, the proprietary one-week sell/buy ratios from Vickers Stock Research have moved in a benign direction in the past 14 days, while the broader eight-week readings from Vickers have mostly stayed put as they still include several weeks of insider bearishness (profit-taking?) in the final trading weeks of 2020.

VIATRIS INC has an Investment Rating of BUY; a target price of $33.000000; an Industry Subrating of High; a Management Subrating of High; a Safety Subrating of High; a Financial Strength Subrating of High; a Growth Subrating of Medium; and a Value Subrating of High.
